140486921.review:
⭐⭐/5 - It was ok

I recently played Half-Life Opposing Force, which I started right after playing Half-Life's "remake" - Black Mesa. It was exciting to revisit the Black Mesa facility and experience the story from a fresh perspective, especially after the immersive army training at the beginning. The first few chapters were enjoyable, even though the graphics and physics were not as impressive as in Black Mesa.

Happiness didn't last very long. Bugs and AI stupidness occupied my gameplay - I got stuck in walls a hell of times, and AI teammates tried to kill me a lot because of some glitchy behaviour. It became so frustrating that I had to force myself to finish the game. But by the end of the game, the gameplay became much more enjoyable, and I am not sure why. There were fewer bugs, and the final boss Gene Worm (nice guy), was a thrilling challenge.

Overall, I found the Opposing Force DLC to be overly tedious and less engaging compared to the main game and Blue Force. While I would recommend it to hardcore fans of Half-Life, I wouldn't suggest it to more casual players like myself. Skipping this DLC in 2023 won't take anything away from your overall Half-Life experience.

UPD: After this review and retrospective view of Blue Shift, I remembered in detail the new mechanics and bosses that Opposing Force introduced. So, if you're seeking Half-Life gameplay and epic boss fights, you will definitely enjoy this one.

139042660.review:
TLDR: An extra slice of cake, but it’s got broken glass in it. 

[b][u]General Thoughts/Overview:[/u][/b]

I remember HL:OF very fondly… Coming back to it, I’m not sure why. 
The plot is near identical to half-life, but taken from the point of view of one of the invading soldiers, who is somehow turned into a good guy. The big additions are new aliens, more guns, and squad tactics. Fight your way through different parts of the base, with a few familiar sites, and deal with the invasion on a different front. 
I’ve always wondered if this was a retcon, where the military suddenly isn’t an antagonist. The plot seems to try to direct it as such, shifting blame despite the events of the base game itself. 
still, onwards.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
[list][*] No Xen levels. Beyond a few brief sequences the game is blissfully short of Xen, which is a terrible positive, but it’s still a positive. 
[*] The game feels decidedly Half-Life. It feels put together with the same care and attention to detail as the first, but suffers the same flaws because of it. For its time, though, it made it a strong expansion.
[*] The new enemies and weapons all feel different and provide a new experience, expanding on the ideas of the base game. They feel well placed, and the only question that pops into my mind is ‘Where were they?’ Which is a standard issue when trying to fit an expansion inside the very same space as the original.  
[/list]

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
[list][*] Saves are bugged, mouse is bugged, game crashes, and when things are running ‘smoothly’, they aren’t smooth. The game has issues performing at every step and it’s as frustrating as it sounds.
[*] Friendly fire, isn’t. The clinging to realism, where American soldiers spend more time shooting their allies than enemies, is laudable, but a bit on the chin. It was when one of my squaddies lobbed a grenade directly into the cluster of his team mates, who were in cover and not even in the same direction as the aliens, killing all of them, that I just decided to stop bringing the soldiers along. It improved my battle performance no end. 
[*] The extra weapons led to bloat for me, where I found myself cycling through all the menus looking for the gun I wanted. 
[/list]

[b][u]Suggested improvements:[/u][/b]
 [list][*] FIX. THE. BUGS. 
[*] Condense the weapons down into a meaningful few and ditch the rest. 
[*] Give the AI some AI, so they can be of use.
[/list]


[b][u]Overall Recommendation:[/u][/b]

Overall I’d give this a miss these days. 

It doesn’t bring much to the story, it doesn’t play hugely well, and it just isn’t all that much fun. It’s the leftovers of a great meal that’s been left out overnight - it contains all the right elements, all the same tasty bits, but they just aren’t the same. 

But if you [i]really[/i] want a little more? It'll do it for you just fine.

138111783.review:
TL;DR. Opposing Force is a drab, lifeless mod that tries to stuff far too many ideas in to a small amount of play time. In general it feels like amateurs made it and indulged themselves whilst doing it. I'd avoid, as it's not very engaging to play, and play other games/HL mods instead. e.g. Go play 'Echoes' or 'They Hunger'.

In full:

When I played this in my yoot, I loved it. Half-Life was amazing, this was more HL, therefore it was amazing. Though looking back I barely remember anything other than the nightvision and the machine gun. I don't even remember the bosses. Could that be because it's simply been 20 years?

Well, now as I play it, 20 years on, I see how flawed asnd forgettable it is. Playing it on the back of HL1 it feels completely amatuerish. I've played _a lot_ of HL mods and TCs over the years, both single- and multi-player, and this really pales in comparison to a lot of them.

The mod is completely uninspired. It relies mainly on taking familiar places, set-pieces, weapons and enemies from HL, giving them a slight twist, and then repackaging them for you. However they didn't understand the ethos Valve had when making Half-Life, and this is clear from just the training room, e.g. you're forced to listen to huge amount of cliche drill sergeant chatter, whereas the original HL hazard course practically allowed you to speed run the entire thing. 


It's clear when playing Half-Life that a huge amount of love and attention went into each level, making every area feel alive and like a "real" place, and a large amount of testing went in to make the subtle cues that direct the player's flow state work like magic. We'd come to know such polish as a hallmark of Valve. 

No such care has been taken with the majority of the levels in this game. OP4 simply does not have the je ne sais quoi of Half-life. The vast majority of the levels are boring, square boxes with the wrong footsteps sounds applied to them and ZERO atmospheric sounds applied. You spend the vast majority of the game clumping around listening to that classic "half-life concrete footstep" sounds. It rarely tries to drop those timely music tracks that HL performed so well just before a battle or something interesting. Most of the major "set piece" battles were a thrill to take-part in in HL, whereas in OP4 they're just boring shooting galleries. 

Gearbox also often made that rookie HL mapper mistake of trying to make large open areas, which doesn't work well with HL's BSP tree engine, as it will happily bring a modern computer to it's knees if you give it an open enough arena. So I imagine that's why all of those open arenas are so square and boring -- they were desperate trying to go "big" whilst also saving on brushes and portals. Valve knew HL's limitations and allowed them to guide the level design, but I guess Gearbox's short turnaround time on making the game meant they lacked any such experience, and it's obviously something the HL community had yet to learn by the time of OP4's release.

But even ignoring the engine problems Gearbox show a general lack of experience in designing fun experiences. In general OP4 makes the mistake of adding "more more more" without any tact or sense on how to apply that. It's completely misguided and leaves everything feeling crowded. A good example is it adds a large number of weapons and keeps the majority of the old ones. You have fully stocked roster. But you have so many that you can barely use them all before completing the game, and it makes managing battles with HL's inventory a pain as now you have 2 more categories and each category has a million weapons. 

They clearly had more ideas than production budget when developing this mod and it's a classic example of scope creep.

Other short examples of Gearbox's eyes being bigger than their belly: 

* "Let's have them play the soldier!" Cool. But you completely forget to address the whole "shooting civilians" thing. Why is Shepherd nice but the ones we see in HL will happily shoot everything?

* The rope system. You use it like, twice in the entire game. It's a colossal waste of development time and the player's time learning it. It also looks stupid.

* The squad system is fun, but rarely serves any functional purpose.

* The portal gun is beyond useless. It effectively converts 40 uranium into a few health packs or batteries. But after the 5th or so Xen map it starts to recycle them and doesn't even repopulate the spawns, meaning the portal gun's second fire stops being useful 1/3 of the way through the game! But those Xen levels are clearly loaded into each main map, as the portal is instant with no loading, which presumably also contributed to the memory pressure and hence their more drab main environments. The Xen levels themselves are also drab, flat and empty, I assume for the same reason. There's very little Xen flora or fauna when compared to stock Xen.

* Also the Xen levels have the wrong gravity? You don't float as much. 

* It added a nightvision mode, in lieu of the flashlight, but it's ugly and useless and the times when it IS requires are really tedious.

* The monsters and weapons themselves are fun, however. Except the two melee weapons. Why add a knife AND a wrench? Especially as the wrench is redundant -- the knife does a better job at killing monsters AND at smashing boxes. There's no need for the wrench. It's just wasteful bloat. But I think they needed to cut most of the original weapons to allow their new ones to shine. 

* There were quite a lot of jumping and environmental puzzles. I quite liked them, but they weren't paced well with the combat, so they often felt tedious, and they all took place in those drab boxy environments. They also over-use box-smashing.

* Too much gman, ruining his mystique. 

It's kind of ironic that OP4 adds lots of stuff to HL, but rarely did it add anything worth remembering even 1 hour after playing it, let alone 20 years.

Люблю серию Half-Life, особенно первую часть. Решил пройти хваленной всеми DLC, и что же я увидел.

-Как человек с опытом в Hammer (программа для редактора уровней), такое ощущение, что на момент создания данного дополнения левел-дизайнеры из Gearbox Software впервые прикоснулись к этой программе. Куча мелких недочетов в маппинге.

-Рваное повествование. Всю игру ты идешь хрен знает куда и хрен знает зачем. После финальной битвы с боссом тебя сразу же забирает G-Man, однако я не вижу в этом никакого толкового объяснения, ведь кто это кальмаро-подобное существо нам не говорят, и о его роли тоже. Нихиланта в конце первой части например объяснили, соответственно ты знаешь кого ты убиваешь и зачем. И понимаешь зачем G-Man забирает тебя в стазис. Здесь же кроме слов охранника что внизу есть какая-то мерзотная нечесть нам больше ничего не объясняют. Так же во время прохождения встречаются уровни из первой части, которые добавлены скорее ради галочки.

-Некоторые механики которые в обучении нам показывают и как бы "хвастаются" на деле в игре используются всего несколько раз, что довольно обидно. Говорю я его про веревки и солдат разной специальности, в особенности инженера.

-Хоть и многие говорят о разнообразии врагов здесь, я с этим поспорю. Примерно в середине игры все оригинальные противники "забываются" и остаются только новые, а их здесь всего 3 (солдат в черной одежде не считаю, это те же солдаты из первой халвы, но с другой моделькой)

Из хорошего:

+Разнообразие вооружение, одна из главных причин по которой так хвалят это дополнение. Особенно понравилась механика телепортации в мир Зен при помощи Displacer (Так называется "Портальная пушка")

+Наличие новых механик которые хоть и немного (описано в третьем минусе), но делают игру разнообразней.


Как мне кажется, это была проба пера от Gearbox, в Blue Shift все сделано хоть и в меньшем масштабе, но лучше.

135719967.review:
For all the good things in here there's about 3 that annoy me. Opposing force has some fun weapons and is a neat side story to the original Half-Life that is fun for the first few hours.
 
After about the halfway point there isn't a single enemy encounter that isn't incredibly annoying with either way too many enemies thrown at you, too many overpowered enemies in one spot or just generally not giving you enough health pickups. All the difficulty feels either unfair or artificially induced from going to fights few little HP.

While the new weapons are fun, they're incredibly situational and mostly not as fun as what was in base HL. Also many seem to overlap in function far too much with other weapons in the game or are not distinct enough from the weapons they replaced from base HL. Overall the weapon sandbox feels a little confused and poorly thought out.

Only two of the new enemy types are remotely fun to fight, with the more fun of the two being hardly utilized. The others put the base game's most obnoxious foes to shame by a mile

To top it off the final boss is (admittedly far less annoying than base HL's) incredibly lame and far too easy

If you are in a pinch and desperate for more Half-life I suppose it would do, it's not awful. Just not something I ever see myself coming back to. If you snag this in a bundle I guess it's worth a shot but as for buying it on it's own, I'd just save the cash.

135518064.review:
This Half-Life is a little odd. Gearbox Software and Valve Software are credited as co-creators of the game, but the game does not live up to the quality level set by the original Half-Life, or even the Half-Life expansion Half-Life: Blue-Shift of which I am a big fan. You reach a point in the game where you are fighting against are very strong aliens who don’t die easily, and you can’t even replenish your ammunition. Also during these moments, health pick-ups are rare. You’re facing marines more powerful than you. You pour bullets into them, but they’re still standing and shooting you. Though it seems alright at the start, the expansion pack really isn’t worth loading.

While the original Half-Life had serious puzzle solving, there is basically one puzzle in this game, though it was fun to solve. The final boss is neat, although amazingly, the game will not finish with OpenGL graphics selected. I was playing on Linux, and switched to the Windows machine to see the ending because the end of the game just doesn’t happen on Linux. I would have expected much better bug testing for such a high-profile franchise. Surely they could have made a patch?

Also disappointing are the lack of good music tracks. The original Half-Life was ahead of its time with quality techno / electronica, but I remember only one half-decent track, and that was all. Graphics are on par with the original, as you would expect.

This is my least favorite Half-Life.

Never reviewed a game on Steam, but I had to speak against the consensus on this one. HL1 is still a great game and mostly holds up today, but this outsourced (heh) expansion does not. 

I will probably play it to completion but my qualms so far are:

1. Environments are drab and boring: you're constantly wandering around a grey corridor listening to the same 1-second clip of electricity crackling. Very poor sense of atmosphere.

2. "Puzzles" are both cryptic and mind-numbing: often-times the solution to clearing a room is simply waiting for a scripted event to finish.

3. Horrible jump vertical: you need to crouch-jump to overcome a milk carton. Surely a soldier is more athletic than this? I know crouch-jump is in the original, but this game makes you jump on boxes constantly. 

4. Feels like a chore to play: I'm not given any motive except getting out of the aforementioned boring environments. 

5. I HATE the wrench. 

Positives:

1. New enemies are sort of cool. 

2. The knife is fun, but it's not our beloved crowbar.

Overall I would not recommend this Gearbox take on HL1, it feels very much a bootleg of the original rather than something which "expands" it.

I have to say, of all the Half Life experiences I've played, this entry was very disappointing. While I understand the game is a product of its time, I found the original Half Life to be far more enjoyable than this expansion. 

For a game that positions the player as the HECU sent in to drive back the Alien incursion and to silence the Science team, you do very little to embrace the "opposing force" role. If anything, the vast majority of the games events are skipped as you're unconscious for most of it. You're just a survivor who has to contend with very annoying enemy design and worthless marine allies. Only this time without any of the intrigue that built up to the battle of Xen. I did not like most of the new additions to the Aliens, especially the Shock Troopers. (and their bargain bin headcrabs) Damage dealt to them felt disproportionate at times. Sometimes you would one bang them, others would take entire magazines before going down, at which point they will likely have nailed you a few times despite blasting them to pieces.

As for the level design, while I definitely enjoyed some of the claustrophobic environmental hazard segments, the level design at times felt very unintuitive. Certain gaps in walls don't look like you can squeeze through when you actually can despite having failed several times. Lighting in the levels sometimes have this awful issue where you cannot see regardless of whether you have Night Vision on or off. My favourite part was when I soft locked my game on EVERY SINGLE LIFT! Not sure why this bug exists, but for some reason you will get glued to the floor and unable to break free whenever a lift stops and reaches its destination, unless you bunny hop. Ridiculous bug that should have been patched years ago.

As for the story, its not very interesting and has never since been brought up by future instalments.

130615012.review:
Heavily opinionated review incoming, take it with a grain of salt.

Going in, I've only heard good things about this game. Endless praise of it's design, mechanics, story; purely 9-10/10 reviews, wherever I went that had Half-Life discussion, Opposing Force was sure to be mentioned. I was led to believe there really was a reason for the high-and-mighty acclaim. The cream of the crop, Goldsrc Half life at it's peak.
Alas, after a full playthrough (on hard difficulty), I do not see what makes this game be held in such high regard. I ended up dissapointed, so much so I longed for it to end soon by around 3/4ths of the game. This game's shortcomings ended up preventing me from having as much fun as I anticipated going in. By no means is it a truly awful game, nor simply bad, though the game felt like a convoluted mess of ideas that could have been thought out better. I would still recommend the game to fans of Half life, though I'd advise them not to expect absolutely too much.
1. Adrian himself
Lets discuss Adrian Shepard, the franchise's tacti-cool protagonist who was seen once and never again.
While several interactions throughout the game characterize him as a valiant leader and a hardy fighter, I feel that he falls short of what makes the other protagonists so interesting.
What I feel made Gordon and Barney feel special in comparison to the typical FPS protagonist of the time, was their rise to action. Both of them pre-incident happened to just be some Joe-Schmo's working at their regular boring job, who later happened to be the right man in the wrong place. They didn't have much combat or leadership experience at all; their rise to heroism was made up of pure improvisation. 
That's not the case for Shepard however, who falls into the general trope of the stranded super-soldier, much akin to the likes of Doom Guy or Master Chief. Shepard is objectively a cool figure and a formidable face, yet he pales in comparison to what made the other 2 HL1 protagonists intriguing, by expanding their motive and their connection to the environment. Doom guy's in this game, neat, but it doesn't add much...
Playing as an HECU soldier, you'd expect right from the get-go to engage in combat with Black Mesa facility and even attempt to exchange fire with Freeman himself...
The game has none of that. The most you'll see is the radio operator making his speech to pull the troops out (coinciding the end of Surface Tension in HL1), and right after a soldier pushing one of the scientists. Adrian along with all of the other soldiers haven't recieved any orders, even any elaboration as to why they were there in the first place. This just feels like a missed opportunity to characterize Shepard and his fellow men, and the story could have been enhanced by adding in a moral dilema whether or not to follow orders or spare the innocent lives of the Black Mesa personel. What could have made you truly feel like the "Opposing Force" is entirely left out, which I feel hurts the game's story.
2. Weapons
One of the major factors that I see this game get praised for the most (and what I've inversely seen as a common criticism of Blue Shift) is the "NEW WEAPONS! WOWZA!!"
The game features a majority of HL1's arsenal (barring the Tau Cannon and Gluon gun), along with a new wide variety of new toys to play with.
The thing is with these, I feel that the game added too many new weapons for its own good. Let's go over the new arsenal featured in game:
I did quite enjoy the pipe wrench, charging up shots to instantly gib many lower-level enemies is satisfying, and it's viable throughout the entirety of the game. A good addition.
The combat knife sounds interesting on paper, given it's pretty much a reskin of the crowbar, while stabbing a human enemy from behind will instantly kill them. I'm a fan of backstab mechanics in games such as TF2 and Counter Strike, yet, in this game I couldn't name a single instance where it would be more practical to sneak up on an enemy from behind (which is quite difficult to achieve in the first place), rather than just shoot at them with your primary firearm.
The Desert Eagle is a sweet upgrade over the already stellar colt revolver, this was my most used weapon throughout the game.
The following weapons however, are where I feel things get iffy.
The barnacle grappling hook is ridiculous and funny as hell, though from the time you get it up to the game's end, it feels underutilized, only a tool you need to use thrice, and not much other than a headcrab killer (funny how theres no headcrab appearances after it's introduction).
The machine gun was neat, sure. It's like the SMG but actually combat-viable. I didnt find it too satisfying to use though, not like how people make it out to be...
Shock roach is basically this game's equivalent to the hivehand, not much to say about it.
I couldn't name one instance where I decided "Hmm, spore launcher sounds like a good weapon choice!" Every time I used it was just to get it out of my inventory.
The sniper rifle was a good mirror to the crossbow, though my gripe is that it felt too powerful, considering bodyshots would instantly kill any Black Ops. Granted, it did get me through Foxtrot Uniform to Worlds Collide, but I feel that it's an unbalanced weapon.
Displacer cannon was one of the opportunies I felt was most missed out on. Primary fire deletes enemies, simple as. It's the weapon of choice for any interaction with Voltigores. Secondary fire just feels like an insult however. It's introduction in "We are not alone" would lead you to believe it's foreshadowing the importance of Xen later on in the game, and I anticipated to explore both Black Mesa and Xen across every chapter. No, Xen in this game just serves as a place to trade uranium for health and ammo (which is still appreciated, considering how stingy the game often gets with resources). What could have been a fun tool to switch up your action ends up leaving a lame impression.
But the overwhelming arsenal featured in this game just ends up being tedious to work around, with weapon switching becoming a pain the farther you progress later in the game, and many of your armaments just become obsolete. The game could have used less item bloat, benefitting from a neater inventory of weapons that are done well and are practically usable. The high amount of poorly executed ideas ends up dampening the overall experience.
3. Enemies:
Somethings up with the game once you start actively dreading combat of any sort. 
The problem with the Black Ops units is the map design that makes them tedious to fight at times, with several instances of you being  weakened regardless of your state before. I disliked the inclusion of assassins as regular enemies. In Half-Life, they appeared a grand total of 2 times, but both those encounters felt engaging and had you thinking ahead, cautiously coming up with ways to outsmart them. In Opposing Force they just end up being annoying as HELL. 
And the RACE X ALIENS, god damn, pretty much NONE of them are fun to fight against. Their inclusion just feels both goofy and frustrating. Plus the final boss ended up being comically easy and anticlimatic. race x is lame lmao

Conclusion:
Looking back, damn I really lambasted this game. I genuinely do feel that alot of the issues this game end up detracting from what couldve been a absolutely magnificient expansion. I notice alot of slander against Blue Shift due to it being a generally less ambitious and very short game; but I believe that with the few things that  Blue Shift did, it did them right. This is what causes Opposing Force to suffer for me the most, the lack of development and reinforcement in alot of the design and gameplay elements prevent the game from shining as bright as it could. It still is a fun game, just not at all what I've been led to expect from hearing the Half Life fanbase.

Ah also, Paul Blart's in this game, hell yeah he's a real homie.

Мне не слишком нравится эта поделка, но нельзя не учесть, что этот мод масштабный, с более хорошим сюжетом, интересными решениями в маппинге, делался одним человеком и за бесплатно, а не студией разработчиков за зарплату.

Уж не обессудьте, что этот обзор превращается из обзора Opposing Force в обзор пользовательских модификаций, но не могу не порекомендовать модификации, сходные по тематике. Солдатские HL1 моды, которые пусть и вышли в недавнее время, смогут достойно заменить поппосинг форсе:

129055771.review:
Although boasting some good new weapons and creature designs, Opposing Force mostly feels like a less-iconic and less well-executed version of the original Half-Life, which means it struggles to hold up well more than two decades after its release.

Version played: Steam, played on Steam Deck
Play time: 10 hours
Gameplay: 45/100
Story: 25/100
Graphics and Design: 70/100
Audio: 75/100
Fun factor: 60/100
Replay value: 20/100

Overall grade: 63/100

Pros / Cons Summary

Pros
• (Gameplay) The weaponry is better than in the original game. There's a sniper rifle!
• (Gameplay) Many gameplay elements are repeated in a lesser form from the original Half-Life, but the original was so good that the results are still OK.
• (Graphics and Design) The new creatures are few but they're generally well-designed.
• (Graphics and Design) There are a couple of cool visual moments.

Cons

• (Story) There's no story at all here, other than that you're a marine and are working your way through Black Mesa. The environmental storytelling of the original game is almost entirely absent.
• (Gameplay) The AI is dismal when viewed through a modern lens.
• (Gameplay) The AI enemies feel cheap. 
• (Gameplay) It's unnecessarily difficult. Get ready to save and load a lot.
• (Gameplay) Some new movement types fall flat, especially the ropes.
• (Graphics and Design) The level design is pretty boring.
• (Graphics and Design) The game is a little too enamored of night vision, and this seems to have impacted the amount of effort the developers put into properly lighting many areas.

Steam Deck notes: I played it docked in 4k while connected to my TV. There wasn't so much as a hitch. I used a standard Xbox Wireless Controller and a slightly modified version of the default control scheme (I like to put the screenshot key on the 'capture button' and I messed with the right stick sensitivity curve). If you're playing this way, make sure you've got auto-aim on in the settings!

122037120.review:
Главный недостаток этого DLS – диссонанс с основной Half-Life. Если DLS Half-Life: Blue Shift было и заметно короче оригинала и оружия в нём было меньше, что объяснялось второстепенной важностью истории охранника Барни Калхаун, по сравнению с историей Гордона Фримена, то в Half-Life: Opposing Force, перебор чувствуется буквально во всём из-за чего становится непонятно, а кто вообще является главным персонажем мира Half-Life – Гордон Фримен или капрал Шеппард? Ведь если судить по Opposing Force, капрал вполне может быть главным героем Half-Life. Но тогда это никак не соответствует продолжению истории, т.е. то, что мы увидим в Half-Life 2. Другими словами, если принять историю капрала Шеппарда, то где капрал в Half-Life 2? Получается, мы либо принимаем Opposing Force, но получаем диссонанс глядя на Half-Life 2 либо признаём Opposing Force неудачным дополнением, которое слишком сильно приблизилось к основной Half-Life с Гордоном Фрименом. Моя отрицательная оценка связана по большей части именно с этой нестыковкой основного сюжета и этого дополнения. Ну не может быть тут никакого капрала Шеппарда, который бы также активно участвовал в истреблении монстров как Гордом Фримен, ибо он не является ключевым персонажем мира Half-Life, а значит его история, как и история охранника, должна была бы быть короче и менее разнообразной. Если посмотреть на то оружие что доступно Шеппарду, то окажется, что он вооружён лучше, чем Фримен. Но так не должно быть! И что это за финальный босс? Это же прямая заявка на равное положение с Фрименом. А если посмотреть на то, как часто капрал встречается с G-man, то получится что он, а не Фримен, является главным действующим лицом. Но так не должно быть! Именно поэтому Blue Shift намного лучше, в плане логики сюжета, чем неповоротливое и явно противоречащее основному сюжету, дополнение Opposing Force.

Вторым главным недостатком является количество и внешний вид оружия. Начиная с гаечного ключа и ножа (вот зачем, зачем два вида одного и того же оружия?!) и вплоть до снайперской винтовки, которая выглядит настолько скучно и не интересно, что кажется что это не Half-Life, а какая та совсем другая игра. Зачем было добавлять новое оружие, не убрав старое, не понятно. Если в обычной Half-Life оружия было вполне достаточно, и всё оно было и уникальным и полезным для каждой ситуации, то в Opposing Force несколько вариантов оружия просто не используется. Какой смысл добавлять пулемёт, если есть автомат? Зачем добавили новое инопланетное оружие, которое отличается от остального боекомплекта только внешним видом? Уникальность Half-Life состоит в том, что каждое оружие является уникальным, неповторимым и очень тщательно проработанным. Здесь же оно выглядит ужасно и не является уникальным от слова совсем. Получилось, что разработчики добавили новое оружие только ради самого факта добавления чего-то нового, из-за чего всё новое оружие совершенно не вписалось в концепцию игры. Просто сравните, как качественно проработан арбалет и как нелепо выглядит снайперское ружьё или пулемёт.

Враги. Тут тоже всё плохо, начиная с финального босса и заканчивая новым/старым спецназом, с тем отличием, что он отличается от HECU только чёрным камуфляжем и… однообразностью. Вы серьёзно, ребята? Давайте вспомним врагов в основной Half-Life. Каждый враг является уникальным и непохожим. А что тут нам предложили? Тот же спецназ, но только теперь он одет в чёрное и охотится на тех, кто охотится на Гордона Фримена, вместе с действительно уникальным врагом – женщинами-убийцами. Это и по сюжету и просто согласно здравому смыслу какой-то сюр. Как? Зачем? Так кто и против кого воюет? С монстрами разработчики также впали в банальность. Как они соотносятся с сюжетом про Гордона Фримена, ведь получается, что он избежал встречи с самыми опасными врагами, в отличие от капрала. Но даже оставим это и зададим себе вопрос: а насколько они уникальны? Ну, предположим, разработчикам хотелось что-то новое добавить. Но неужели нельзя было ограничиться одним типом, но сделать его по-настоящему уникальным? Я уж молчу про то, что один новый тип монстров воспроизводит старый вариант, только более живучий и более опасный (возможно его-то и можно было оставить). Остальные, особенно гигантское скачущее нечто, на которое нужно потратить чуть ли не весь боезапас, вообще тут лишнее. А можно ли, выпустив DLS, создать что-то, не предлагая игроку обязательно новое вооружение и новых врагов? Абсолютно! Можно было рассказать историю HECU, т.е. кто они, как очутились в Чёрной Мезе и самое главное, что с ними происходило, ведь в основной Half-Life они также активно воевали с монстрами. Для DLS этого было бы вполне достаточно. Другими словами, можно было направить все усилия разработчиков на дизайн уровней, написание истории и создание специальных скриптов для масштабных событий, типа крупных взрывов обрушения лифта, попадание ракет, появление монстров и пр. Т.е. все силы можно было бы направить на создание непротиворечивой, но дополняющей историю Гордона Фримена. И это я молчу про невозможно тупых союзников, которые застревают всегда и везде (возможно ими и стоило ограничиться в качестве «нового вооружения», но сделать их более полезными?). 
Ах да, начало игры тоже невообразимо скучное, которое не только не знакомит нас с игрой, новым персонажем и миром, который был до катастрофы, но и выглядит оно совершенно заурядно.

А есть ли в этом дополнении что-то, что мне понравилось? Пожалуй, только реплики, которые издают члены нашей команды. Вот они получились довольно забавными (у меня все игры на английском, так что я сужу сугубо по оригиналу). Всё остальное разработчики не просто не улучшили или, хотя бы оставили без изменения, но ухудшили. На фоне основной Half-Life и дополнения Blue Shift, это DLS просто ужасно и показывает, как не нужно делать дополнения.

121669598.review:
Opposing force is an interesting take on a somewhat more action-focused Half-Life, bringing in a ton of new weapons, new enemies and environments. Unfortunately, it is not lacking in shortcomings too.

Level-design is nowhere near as good as in Half-Life and it seems to constantly recycle concepts from it, but with a different monster or a modified layout along with a significant degradation in quality and pacing. There was also at least an instance where enemy spawns were placed right in front of a loading trigger, making it easy to accidentally walk through it while fighting them.
Some of the new weapons were fun to mess around with, but in general they seem to have been added just for the sake of it and are either rarely ever needed or overlap each other in functionality too much. The nonstop fights against the same enemy types also made some sections tedious to get through, especially in the second half of the game. In addition, dialogue felt like I was watching a mockbuster of Half-Life, with G-Man feeling particularly out of character. The depiction of HECU soldiers is also very whitewashed when compared to the original.

Functionality-wise it doesn't seem to have aged very well, becoming quite apparent in the final quarter of the game. It often crashed on load, and it's very easy to get stuck in elevators. I had a few deaths where the physics system bugged out and just decided that my character shouldn't be alive anymore. Loading screens could interrupt music, and there was also a section near the end which has a sound effect that is ridiculously distorted and louder than everything else. 
Both the friendly and enemy AIs are buggy and NPCs have a tendency to get stuck as well as constantly shoot friendlies. These issues are greatly amplified by the layout of some levels.

118068657.review:
Mi reseña para esta expansión de Half-Life es negativa, aunque es una lástima, porque el juego base me parece que es una obra irrepetible, pero esta expansión está mal diseñada, como si fuera un mod cutre del juego original.
Para empezar, hay secciones en las que, estando a poca vida, aparecen vortigaunts o grunts que me matan enseguida, teniendo que cargar partida no una, sino varias veces hasta que consigo librarme de ellos, cayendo esta entrega en el ensayo y error (cosa que ya sucedía en ocasiones en el Half-Life, pero acentuándose en Opposing Force).
Otro fallo que tiene el juego son algunas decisiones de diseño cuestionables. En uno de los primeros capítulos del juego, estaba rompiendo unas cajas para ver si encontraba suministros. Por supuesto, para no tardar tanto, mantenía pulsado el boton de ''disparo'' con la llave inglesa. ¿Qué puede salir mal? Pues el hecho de que, en una de esas cajas, había un lanzacohetes, y claro, en estos juegos, cuando coges un arma nueva, se selecciona automáticamente. El resultado es que el pobre Shepard se lanzó accidentalmente un cohete en la cara. Aquí el problema no es que me suicidara de una forma tan tonta. Aquí la pregunta es: ¿Qué sentido tiene que, en una etapa tan temprana del juego te den un arma tan poderosa como un lanzacohetes?
La guinda sobre el pastel llega en el capítulo de Fuego Aliado. En este capítulo, llego a un lugar donde se encuentra un médico, además de unos Black Ops, que resisten una cantidad ridículamente alta de balas, pero bueno. Resulta ser que, por alguna extraña razón, el médico, al rato, me ataca sin que yo le haya atacado a él. Lógicamente intento defenderme, pero si le mato, el juego me tira una pantalla de Game Over. Básicamente el juego se me ha bugueado y no puedo continuar, porque si no le ataco, él me mata, pero si le ataco, Game Over.
En resumen, esta expansión, aunque tiene buenas ideas (como el tema de las cuerdas o las radios y los compañeros militares y sus roles) no llega al nivel de calidad del juego base. El juego en general está mal diseñado, como si Gearbox no entendiera las cosas que hizo bien Half-Life.
Lo único salvable es el momento en el que el alien de la raza X mata al guardia de seguridad. Esa escena es impagable.

116610916.review:
Yet another game that makes me wish I there was a "maybe" recommendation option, but given there isn't, I'm going to have to go with no.

Half-Life: Opposing Force is basically just more Half-Life, but not as good. If you really, [i]really[/i] want more Half-Life, Opposing Force will probably do it for you. There's some pretty neat ideas scattered throughout. But put up against how great Half-Life is really makes you appreciate a lot of the clever visual cuing and other level design tricks that Valve uses to make one cohesive journey.

There is some neat new stuff introduced in the game, but a number of them are pretty flawed. You can get AI squad members to fight with you, occasionally, for a little bit. They aren't particularly competent, and can't navigate difficult terrain, so even if they do survive for a while, eventually you'll be forced to leave them behind. You can climb and swing from ropes, but it never quite works the way you expect it to, and ultimately just made me wish they had all been just ladders, instead. Night vision goggles replace the Half-Life flashlight. While the original Half-Life flashlight is pretty bad, having your whole screen green for long periods of time is also annoying, and with the amount of dark sections in this, you better get used to green. Also, the voltigore nests are just annoying.

That said, there are some nice new weapons included, including a couple alien weapons that are actually useful, unlike the Hivehand. There are some neat new enemies, and getting to see some areas from the base game from a different perspective is neat.

Ultimately, this isn't a bad expansion, but it also isn't easy to recommend. With the number of truly great games out there, I'd say Opposing Force can be safely skipped by most.

109068636.review:
A very dated game that basically does what Half Life did but poorly. There are some more chaotic levels that involve less tactic and more RNG, it brings back those terrible platforming levels on Xen (albeit not many thankfully) and puzzles that require you to do things in a specific sequence that's not explained or hinted at or otherwise risk getting soft-locked and starting over again (i.e. that Pit Worms chapter). In between these events is mostly silence occasionally broken up by a random alien spawning out of nowhere. The sewer level is probably the worst offender being both buggy and tedious.

And don't get me started on the buggy AI, Black OPS will have Einsteins IQ when attacking you but your allies will struggle to commit to the basic task of following you even though path-finding is literally built into each map. I have no idea how they messed that up. Oh yeah, and if you thought the Black OPS were challenging enough the game spawns them behind you in the chapter 'Worlds Collide' just to piss you off.

Now there are some good things about this game; it has a wide selection of weapons, new alien species and some nicely designed areas but I struggle to find anything nice to say other than that.

The result of all this is an exhausting experience that ends up being more frustrating than fun.

105767027.review:
Yeah, I don't know.

It's a game that I enjoy because of how it plays, I like the gunplay and the set pieces but it also hasn't aged well in a multitude of different aspects.

For one, the difficulty is extremely unbalanced, this is an absurdly challenging game at times independently on whether you're playing the game on normal, hard, or easy.

Then there's the level design and some of the game's pacing, a lot of the times I would rely on either the antiquated a.i. to open paths for me, or alternatively, I would get shot by them because I would accidentally get in their crossfires and they weren't smart enough to stop shooting at me, nor did the developers programmed the game to make me invulnerable to the a.i. companion's shots.

Then there was this really obnoxious bug/glitch around the middle of the game where I just couldn't change my weapons, I tried everything I could, exit the game, exit to the menu, save and load, quick save and load, use cheat codes to noclip to a more open area in case that had something to do with it, then I even tried to spawn an rpg, it worked, but it still wouldn't let me change my weapons, I had to reload a save file from 10 minutes since then, then I could progress through the game; but after a while it got boring.

Generally I just sort of remained either frustrated with this game, or disappointed with it because I got bored after a while.

In some cases the path to progress were also fairly cryptic or outright frustrating to play through.

There's some platforming in some Xen areas near the half of the game, those got fairly annoying because of how "floaty" my character felt, at times it would be as if the developers had just deliberately placed the platforms just far enough for you to fell as soon as you ALMOST reached the edge.

Crouch jumping didn't help.

Then there was this part near the end where I just didn't know where to go next, this games are fairly linear for the most part, but here I couldn't for the life of me; find the freaking pathway to progress.

Eventually I did, turns out I had to jump through the broken window of one such elevator, something that I don't think I've ever had to do in any other Half Life game, even in the first game where you have to do a similar thing, you do it by slamming the window pane of the elevator door that's closest to the ground, and the game gives you a ton of hints in its design to let you know this is what you're supposed to do, it even places the crowbar right next to that elevator door.

Overall I just thought it was a cool concept for a game, specially a Half Life game, given that you're playing from the perspective of one of the soldiers that gets to Black Mesa facility; sadly it didn't pay off at the end though, I couldn't bring myself to even finish it.

102639759.review:
Хотелось бы начать с того что я проходил эту игру в два этапа с промежутком в полтора года. Во время первой попытки я, сам того не осознавая, почти прошёл игру, но нервы не выдержали и было принято решение взять перерыв. А второй этап случился совсем недавно, мне пришлось потратить всего несколько часов для завершения начатого.
 С вступлением закончили, преступаем к обзору:
1. Мир: тот же самый. События игры Half-Life Opposing Force происходят параллельно событиям игры Half-Life, по этому мир не изменился.
2. Механики: интересные. Несколько нововведений неплохо разбавляют игру. Механики перекочевавшие из предыдущей игры работают безупречно.
3. Баги: отсутствуют. Мне не попалось ни единого бага. Вполне возможно по тому, что я наиграл слишком мало часов чтобы их встретить.  
 Минусы: 
-Стилистика: устаревшая, хотя мне это не помешало играть.
-Управление: инерционное. После того как вы отпустите клавишу движения, персонаж остановится не сразу, а через несколько секунд, будто двигаясь по инерции.
-Компоновка: неадекватна. Затишье и экшен сменяют друг друга слишком резко, из-за чего игрок не понимает, когда он может перевести дух.
-Нелинейная линейность: сейчас объясню. Игра Half-Life Opposing Force является линейным (коридорным) шутером, но при этом в "коридорах" слишком много бесполезных ответвлений. 
-Финальный босс: личное мнение. Интересная идея загубленная огромным здоровьем червя или кто он там.
Скажу честно, Нихилант был лучше: интереснее, сложнее и как бос чувствовался крепче.
Игра Half-Life Opposing Force не совсем ужасная, но советовать её не могу никому. Если решите играть, то Бог вам в помощь.

101448138.review:
Muy tedioso de jugar. Pasárselo se siente como un trabajo.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*]La exploración es buena. Muchos niveles tienen varias salas interconectadas entre sí. Si pones atención, puedes encontrar lugares con objetos para recoger.

[*]Los sonidos de los enemigos que se oyen a por el mapa funcionan genial para añadir tensión.

[*]Hay armas nuevas respecto al juego original.
[/list]

[h1]Contras:[/h1]
[list]
[*]El manejo del personaje es malísimo. Se mueve demasiado rápido para los espacios tan cerrados en los que tiene lugar la acción. No puedes apuntar bien mientras te mueves en espacios tan pequeños y a distancias tan cortas. Pero si no te mueves rápido, te acribillan. Y el personaje también se desliza al frenar. A eso añade que hay sitios en los que tienes que saltar de altura en altura. Y, si te caes, pierdes un buen pedazo de vida.

[*]Los combates con enemigos son muy tediosos. Se mueven muy rápido, y te acribillan muy fácilmente. Sobretodo, cuando aparecen en tu cara nada más abres una puerta. Aunque no te maten, te quitan más vida de lo que te puedes permitir a largo plazo, para enfrentar los siguientes encuentros. Así que tienes que recargar y repetir casi siempre.

[*]Los soldados vienen corriendo hasta tu cara y te disparan en la cara mientras te echan granadas.

[*]El jefe final es malísimo. Tras pasarte el juego matando alienígenas a base de pegar tiros con distintas armas, al jefe final tienes matarlo disparándole en dos puntos puntos del cuerpo diferentes, con un par de armas especiales que hay colocadas en dos sitios distintos de la sala. Cuando le disparas en los dos sitios, abre un punto débil al que tienes que seguir disparando para matarle. Tras unos segundos, esconde el punto débil, y a repetir. Toda la pelea final consiste en repetir ese proceso varias veces seguidas. Entre iteraciones, hace emerger a un único soldado alienígena normal y corriente de los que has matado a decenas. Por una parte, se agradece que sea fácil. Porque, a esas alturas del juego, sólo tienes ganas de terminarlo cuanto antes y olvidarte ya de él. Pero es que, además de fácil, es soso. No se siente como pelear contra un jefe. Se siente como pasarte 10 minutos dando vueltas por una sala para tocar el mismo par de botones muchas veces. Lo único que se siente como una pelea es matar al enemigo que emerge entre iteraciones. Y eso, al mismo tiempo, se siente como simple relleno. Muy cutre todo.

[*]Para pasar una parte tienes que activar una visión nocturna de la que no te hablan en ningún lado.

[*]Con algunas armas, la mirilla se te fija automáticamente sobre los enemigos al pasarla cerca de ellos. Hace que apuntar a veces sea difícil.

[*]La mirilla de algunas armas a veces ni se ve. Especialmente con la visión nocturna. Tanto la mirilla como el filtro de visión nocturna son de color verde. Cuesta apuntar.

[*]Errores:
[list]
[*]Algunas puertas funcionan mal. Aunque se puedan abrir, no siempre se abren al darle al botón. Te tienes que acercar y alejar para que se abran. A veces, tienes que hacer eso en varias ocasiones, porque tampoco funciona siempre. En ocasiones, esto pasa mientras hay enemigos que te disparan al otro lado de la puerta, para mejorar las cosas.

[*]El juego está a doblado a castellano a medias. Algunos personajes hablan en ingles. Otros en castellano. Otros dicen algunas frases en un idioma, y otras frases en el otro.

[*]En un nivel, se me empezaron a corromper las partidas guardadas a partir de cierto punto. Al cargar y repetir esa parte, dejó de pasar. Pero podría haber perdido todo el progreso.

[*]No consigo jugar directamente al juego en Steam. Me dice que lo está ejecutando, pero no arranca. He tenido que instalar el [i]Hal-Life[/i] original, abrirlo, y cambiar de juego desde su menú principal.
[/list]

94237069.review:
Imagine if you distilled all the problems with the original Half Life, and made that one game: that is Opposing Force. I haven't finished Opposing Force, and I refuse to. I can look past some of the problems, mostly the graphics and animations, but the fundamental gameplay is just terrible, even compared to Half Life, which I think hasn't aged too well.

Any praise I can give for new weapons, new enemies, and new environments, is meagre in comparison to just how painful an experience this is.

There is a ridiculous amount of platforming, which I don't really mind, but that would be a massive turn off for some.

Half Life has a few too many weapons, so Gearbox decided to add more to fix this problem. This did not work. Half Life's gunplay was never its strongest suit, and the weapons here have most of the same problems.

You're dependent on AI characters to progress at certain points, but their pathfinding breaks if you get more than 10 feet away from them.

It's not hard - it's straight up unfair. I stopped playing when I got to the point where your put in a pitch black maze, you can only see 10 feet ahead of you even with your Night Vision Goggles, and the maze is filled with powerful enemies.

I didn't have too many ammo problems, but health and suit charge are very rare. To top this off, the Autosave is very relaxed, requiring frequent saving or massive losses of time and effort.

I hope Crowbar Collective could do something with this for a Black Mesa-esq re-do, but I'm not counting on it. I'm going to go back to pulling my own teeth out, because it was less painful than this.

84821783.review:
I bought this game so I could play through the entirety of the Half-life franchise, the story is quite enjoyable, however, there are many issues that affect gameplay greatly.

The first problem you are likely to encounter is that you can't actually look around with your mouse without changing a couple of settings, it just gets reset to where it started if do so. The game itself has some really good ideas but the mess of bugs that just get you stuck is painful, I've gotten stuck in elevators, walls, even once in the floor. Loading a quicksave can also crash your game from time to time.


Some parts of the game are also massively frustrating thanks to very rare health and suit refilling opportunities and the resilience of some enemies, there are parts where this feeling is especially present thanks to the stupid amount of enemy spawned in a tiny area, enemies that have a gigantic amount of health in some cases. While battling the enemies in this game you will probably die, a lot, and you will need to respawn, the problem is that many of the autosave points are in areas that will make you repeat a boring vent or a puzzle you've already completed and have to repeat, this issue can of course be avoided by quicksaving, but as mentioned before, it likes to sometimes crash the game. Another problem I think is important is how weapons are handled, there are a lot of new weapons but most of them won't actually get much ammo during the game.

Overall, it's not the worst of games but it does seem like no one play tested it due to the amount of bugs and frustrating instances during the time you spend playing.

Also, Otis stops being used fairly soon and he's so much better than the marines, unlike the marines Otis won't actually shoot you in the back while fighting. He also loves candy, you can't not love him.

In meinen 6,5 Stunden kann ich sagen dass der Anfang mir von der Geschichte wie auch dem Gameplay gefallen hat. Allerdings gibt es einige Jump n' run Elemente und dieses Spiel ist dazu nicht gerade freundlich was die Steuerung angeht.
Hinzu kommt z.B. das vorletzte oder drittletzte Level dass einem einige Gegner entgegen wirft aber dem Spieler kaum Munition sowie Healthpacks zur verfügung stellt.
Dies war einer der Level an dem ich wie vorher mindestens 20 Minuten verbringen hätte können. Weil man mit 12HP aller höchstens drei Treffer einstecken kann bevor man von vorne anfangen muss. Manuelle Speicherstände waren dabei eine große Hilfe.

Die letzten zwei/drei Level habe ich dann schließlich mit dem Command "notarget" abgeschlossen und den Bosskampf am Ende hat mich überrascht. 
[spoiler] Man hat keine Abwechsulng und macht die gleiche Tätigkeit für ca 5 mal, wenn nicht sogar mehr. Es gab keine Musik und man hatte nur dieses Ekelhafte Geräusch von dem Vieh im Ohr. Trotz "Noclip" und "fly" hat dieser Bosskampf sich so gezogen dass ich das Gefühl hatte 10 Minuten wären vergangen.

Für Fans des Franchises sowie Spieler die eher schwere und retro bevorzugen ist es einem Blick wert aber für mich gab es schlicht zu viele frustrierende Stellen.

83924331.review:
前不久通了黑山，按照顺序前来考古/朝圣。忽略画质和建模的年代问题之外，本作的游戏性一点也不输给本体（或者黑山），战斗解谜相得益彰，剧情并不复杂却又引人入胜，是一款只要沉下心就依然能在这个时代好好欣赏的老游戏。

我开了两遍档，玩到1.2小时的地方闪退，不管怎么读档都会在30秒之内继续闪退。验证游戏也没用，把所有设置还原（包括鼠标raw input）也没用，对于我来说这个游戏不具备availability，只好弃了。

我主观上是非常希望这些经典老游戏能够出重置的，这样就不必对着十几二十年前的画面自我高潮。然而炒冷饭也是一门学问，要改的不只是画面建模，连一些游戏机制也要与时俱进。改的多了老玩家不满意，改的少了新玩家难入坑（老游戏模式大多反人类，强行增加难度拉长游戏时间却毫无趣味，在当时文娱刚起步的年代尚且可以忍耐，跟现在的游戏比就无法令人接受了，虽然本作的前1h游戏流程我认为还是可以玩的）卖的好的冷饭作品基本上都是照着紧跟时代的全新作品来立项的，v社也不是什么大厂，有这个资源肯定会优先新作了，所以客观判断半条命重制希望渺茫，有生之年吧。

79672027.review:
I played Half Life 1 sometime in 2019.I finished it and I absolutely loved the game. I think the original Half life aged incredibly well. I finished that game without needing walkthroughs, other than a glitched section with the missile selector and I loved it.

Honestly I was surprised by how well it held up. Pacing, movement, environmental story. It is absolutely a game you can just hop into and enjoy in 2020. 

Having loved Half Life I decided to play Opposing Force since people really seemed to be fond of it. I played and finished Opposing Force on the Hardest difficulty and completed the entire game in just under 4 hours according to Steam. Although I like to explore all parts of the gameworld so if you are going through then I could see it being finished in under 3 hours for the average gamer.

I really have to say, Opposing Force is definitely the worst Half Life game I’ve played and in general one of the worst non-indie games I’ve played.

First big issue I have with the game is the pacing and levels. It feels like an Alien tried to recreate Half Life from memory. There isn’t really the set up of puzzles and other exploration like there was in Half Life, and a lot of the puzzles really amount to using the grappling hook on a super obvious green spot because those are the only things the grappling hook can grab onto. Or flipping a switch, or something very basic. Never really had the Eureka moment when playing.

There is definitely more combat and less hidden areas. A lot of it really feels like combat and then loads of ammo and healing. It's very stop-start rather than a consistent drip of resources. It just feels very very sloppy. I’m not saying chapters like “Residue Processing” were what made Half Life 1 great, but the flow of the game, puzzles, and resource supply were really magical. It was easy to sit down and just play through the game. 

Combat in Opposing Force is really bad. Black ops soldiers take multiple alt-fire shotgun blasts to the head at point blank range to go down. Hit Scanners deal tons of damage so you need to be far enough to take advantage of spread or exploit AI. If you run or stand in the open you die in a few seconds so it’s not really a run and gun, more like use corners to confuse the really bad AI. Some of that is true of Half Life 1 but the level design is so much more complex so a lot of the combat felt more puzzle like and had more options, generally. Half Life combat was never that great, so having a campaign focus on it which removes a lot of the things that supported Half Life combat is pretty bad.

I don’t think I remember the enemies in Half Life 1 being this spongy or having their AI be this bad. It really just feels awful to be shooting something for like 10 seconds straight just to not kill it. Almost all guns are horribly inaccurate which really makes them mesh together. The shotgun feels weak, the AR feels weak. Everything feels weak and unfun to use except explosives, portal gun, and the sniper rifle. The machine gun is OK, it deals more damage than other guns but is inaccurate and I found it more useful for increasing movement speed backwards than actually shooting people most of the time. It’s a lot more effective to run past enemies than fight them and actually not that hard to do.


They added a bunch of alien weapons but none of them are really interesting. A projectile gun that doesn’t need ammo. It’s like the Hivehand but worse and less cool looking. The spore launcher is a ranged explosive that bounces a bit. I don’t know why they added it in a game with a rocket launcher and grenade launcher. We don’t get the extremely distinct and separate feel that we did with the original Half Life. I mean just consider that line up, the Gluon gun was way different from the crossbow, which could be used underwater, which was way different from the MP5. 

Probably the only interesting gun they added was the portal gun. It shoots giant powerful blasts and the alternate fire takes you to Zen to gather resources. Each location on the map has different Zen levels associated with the alternate fire which is pretty neat.




There are these squad mechanics but they are a joke. Squadmates are really more cannon fodder and they can deal friendly fire which killed me a few times. Enemies still seem to focus on you and their following AI is borderline non-functional. You also can’t seem to carry them across the loading screens almost all the time. Generally I just killed them for ammo if I needed it. But sometimes the game will make you fail the mission for killing them because they were needed for scripted events.


The final boss fight uses Goldsource ladders and ropes. Lol it’s horrible. I have no idea what they were thinking when they made this. Horrendous design decisions and really just unenjoyable to play. The goldsource is janky when it comes to movements but jumping around in open spaces can be pretty fun. But all the confined spaces and use of ladders is honestly pathetic. It’s really bad.

Also the game is extremely buggy. I didn’t use a walkthrough for this one but I noticed doors grinded and would not open no matter what. I looked up “door grinding opposing force” and of course it’s a thing. Doors just get stuck and prohibit progress. This happened to me 3 times with essential doors. Sometimes launching an explosive or jumping at it while mashing the use key works. 

I’ve also had save files corrupt. I’ve gotten stuck between level changes, a LOT. Especially a level change with a lift or vent I got stuck and had to keep loading autosaves to try to prevent it. For the vent ones try to be running at top speed before loading for the lifts try to jump before it hits the ground. I know Gearbox is infamous for making broken games, especially their horrific Halo port, but damn it’s like no one actually played this game before shipping it. But I guess I was able to finish it without using the console or anything.

This game does absolutely nothing better than Vanilla Half Life, actually it does everything worse. I would not suggest paying money for it or spending time to play it. It’s like they didn’t learn anything from the original Half Life release.

76899027.review:
Maybe there's something I'm overlooking, but this expansion flat out isn't fun. I respect that it was more ambitious than Blue Shift and did a lot, but this feels like if you took "NES hard", and made it a shooter. It feels like this game's idea of difficulty is repeatedly throwing insanely difficult enemies at you and calling it a day.

I love Half-Life the most when it's this frantic energetic whirlwind of a game exploring the chaotic mess of Black Mesa. Here, the gameplay has been slowly devolving from that, into constant quivering in a corner, clinging on to the last ounces of my life hoping that I'll be able to finally move on. Maybe if you like throwing yourself at a wall over and over, you'll enjoy it, but that isn't for me.

71192348.review:
This expansion has its ups and downs, but the cons heavily outweighed the fun times I had playing this mod.
I love the Half-Life series to death, and this is the only one that I have disliked.
The levels are obscenely difficult, and instead of making it fun to beat such a challenge, they design the enemies to be cheap and annoying to deal with. Don't even get me started on the fucking pit drones.
I played through the campaign in both hard and easy difficulty, and there was absolutely no difference.

The Vortigaunts are placed in ways to ambush the player, but the problem is that they typically damage you when there is nothing you can do about it, since they are either placed in hard-to-kill spots, or you have no ammunition left. There is also a severe lack in medkits during these sections, requiring sv_cheats 1 if you save in a bad spot.

I also had to noclip out of certain floors or walls, because the game is so fucking bad that it lets you get stuck in them.

The final boss was underwhelming as well, and violated the basic rule of the Half-Life series: show a way that you can beat your enemies.
I was stuck on it for a while because HOW THE FUCK AM I SUPPOSED TO KNOW TO SHOOT THE GODDAMN PURPLE BALL?
Throughout the early days of the Half-Life series, balls of energy have been shown to teleport, so I thought that I would have to go in the ball. The game didn't let me.
Then I realized you could shoot out the eyeballs of the alien. Thought that if you shot them out enough times, it would kill it. After about 10 times of shooting out the eyeballs with no change, I realized this wasn't it.

The weapons are also unbalanced. Some guns are weaker than a peashooter, while others are stupidly good. In the end, it doesn't even matter, since you won't have enough ammo to fire these guns in the first place.

Also, who decided to make the Black Ops tanks? You cannot kill them with a FULL SMG MAGAZINE. ON THE EASIEST DIFFICULTY.

That being said, this mod had its moments. During the times when it wasn't obscenely difficult, the campaign was loads of fun to play through. I only recommend this game to the die-hard Half-Life fans, since the only reason I slogged through the frustrating parts of the campaign was to say that I had beaten the whole Half-Life series.

I might play through it another time and edit my review, but for now, I would rather play Hunt Down the Freeman. (Kidding, of course. This expansion wasn't that bad, but it hasn't aged well.)

67693509.review:
I don't know how this game ran in 1999, I was only one year old. But in the year 2020, it's one of, if not THE buggiest, glitch filled game I have ever played. It's got a lot of cool concepts and ideas to it and an awesome story, but it seems like it was coded in windows paint. Some people have the game work perfectly and love it, for me it's a barely functional mess. Yes I've verified the game cache...

Gearbox actually developed this for Valve and it shows by the lack of polish in my opinion. In their credit, they do a really good job of capturing the feel of Half Life 1, but they just cant do it as good... They capture the right feel of the puzzles and lay out, but it just feels sloppier somehow...

You have to quick save at least once a minute because something will constantly break and you'll just die or be stuck in place. I had to reload THE FIRST ROOM of the tutorial at least 4 times before it worked. That's not the only stuff that's broken.

DOORS: You'll constantly find yourself slamming face first into a door that either doesn't open unless you walk away from it 2-3 times, OR you'll have to spam your activate key like it was a quicktime event. They also seem to break the Marines A.I, as they just have the worst time trying to figure out how to walk through one and follow you. 

THE A.I: The A.I in the game is artificial for sure, but not intelligent... Most of the enemies are scripted sequences they they don't break tooo much. They'll spawn, stand in the same spot and let you shoot them. 
Your fellow Marines on the other hand make the nickname "Crayon Eaters" seem to distinguished. You have to keep telling them to keep following you every 5 feet because they forget almost instantly and just stand still. If you do manage to get them to follow you, get ready for a laugh. These poor lemmings will just run back and forth like a child with ADHD. They'll get trapped in doorways, trapped in huge rooms!. If you break eye contact with them they'll forget about you like a baby without object pertinence and just break. If they take the tiniest bit of damage from an explosion, hell if they even SEE an explosion, they yell "Traitor!", and gun you down. Sometimes they'll just break and start shooting you for no reason. Stay behind them because they don't care if your in the line of fire, you get in their way you're just another enemy...

THE DIFFICULTY: It is difficult but not because of the challenges you face, but because of how much this game doesn't want you to have resources. The game is SO stingy with ammo and health, but it'll throw 10 useless guns at you right at the very start. The true challenge of this game is to ever have full health and shields at the same time. There are tons of situations where the game forces you to take damage to progress. That or the sloppy controls just sent you careening into an electric fence or getting yourself stuck on something you're trying to jump over.

THE WEAPONS: It's doesn't really feel like Gearbox had a set sense of direction for this. What I mean is you get the pipe wrench as your first weapon, you think cool! Then no less then 20 secs later, you get a combat knife that makes it look like a wiffle ball bat. The pacing of the new weapons is just so off. Your first gun is the Magnum which kicks ass and is by far your best gun when it comes to a mix of range and damage. The next gun you get is the shotgun which is virtually worthless as with it's EXTREMELY LIMITED range and damage, you're honestly better off with a knife. So then after you get what are "supposed" to better guns you should be getting later, that's when you get the base pistol. The progression just feels so backwards and unfocused. By that time your current guns are way better comparatively.  Most of the weapons in this game are just gimmicky reskins of the ones in Half Life, with only really I believe, the M249 being a new introduction. 

I love Half Life and was super excited to play this, but it is just a nightmare to play with all of the bugs. It's not fun quickloading a sequence 5 times to get it to work. It's disappointing because you can see the potential for awesome fun, but get bogged down by so many technical errors. 

If you love Half-Life, by all means buy it, but be prepared to go online to download some unoffical patches. That or have a lot of patience.

65950685.review:
This expansion is basically Hunt Down the Freeman but released 20 years earlier.

There are some things this game nails, mainly in terms of game mechanics, such as adding climbable ropes or slightly expanding the squad system. There are also interesting new weapon concepts. Also the boot camp tutorial is extremely well done, and it's probably the highlight of the game.

Unfortunately for the expansion, all the new concepts are very poorly integrated. For example, climbable ropes appear maybe 2 or 3 times throughout the entire game. In another case, 2 new types of suit rechargers are teased in the tutorial, military and civilian, and I only saw the military recharger once (I didn't find a single civilian recharger).

Health and suit power pickups are very scarce, and you are often thrown into hordes of enemies. There's one section where you're in a pitch-black maze and are meant to face off against many miniboss-tier enemies, with no ammo or health pickups. On the very last level, you face off against hordes of black-ops, at which point i turned on noclip and godmode because I was tired of this.

At one point, multiple new weapons are introduced very close to each other, with little instructions on how to use them, so I finished the game with about 3 weapons I ended up never using. 

These complaints are just a very small slice of annoyances I had with the expansion. However, I don't feel like writing, so I'll stop here.

Blue shift is a much better expansion, go play that instead.

65117534.review:
Now, I know this is going to get me hate, I get it, we're all Half-Life fans here, but please, hear me out on this one, I have a lot of bases to cover.
To start off, let's just do a quick pros and cons for Opposing Force:
Pros:
New, completely original soundtrack by Chris Jensen
Campaign that is longer than the original Half-Life's
New weapons, characters, enemies, and multiplayer gamemodes to explore
Cons:
gameplay seems incredibly unbalanced in some areas
cool concepts (the xen portal gun) are left relatively unexplored
Bugs, a LOT of bugs.

This brings me to the main reason why I am not recommending Opposing Force right now. The game has unfortunately aged abysmally. Originally, I had thought that my issues were coming from the fact that I was playing on Hard mode. Lord knows "Hard" meant something different in the 90s than it does now, but the further in I went, the more I realized that it wasn't me, it was the game. Weapons that I had picked up and appeared in my hotbar failed to actually register as weapons I had. This was a major problem for several portions of the game, as my rocket launcher, xen portal gun, and machine gun were all effectively missing from my inventory despite the fact that I had them and ammo for them. The second major issue I had was an unavoidable crash near the end of the game. In the parking garage, I would crash every single time I attempted to turn a corner down a ramp, effectively forcing me to use cheats just to finish the game.
Next off, the gameplay itself, while being Half-Lifey, is honestly broken in its own right. Enemies appear to be able to damage the player more than the player can damage them with the same weapon when playing on Hard mode. I know I'm going to be told to just "get good" over this, but a fundamental element of singleplayer, story driven games is that the player feels like their in control. Sure, for things like giant aliens, I can see the reasoning behind why I'm not stronger than them, but Adrian Shephard isn't supposed to be a regular soldier, either, he's supposed to be a Corporal that's equipped with a new, experimental suit of armor akin to the soldier version of the HEV suit. Attacks from Shock Troopers take a minimum of 10 hp off Adrian if he doesn't have any suit power, and believe me, suit power is few and far between in this game. Things like the rope gameplay and use of a night vision instead of flashlight seem arbitrary and unnecessary to me. The rope gameplay itself seems to fail to do its job properly in every place it's in during gameplay, especially during the final boss. Night Vision, on the other hand, is weak and doesn't go out far enough for the player to see in some dark areas of the game where it's an absolute necessity.


[h1] SPOILERS FOR THE STORY BELOW [/h1] 

Opposing Force sees you as Corporal Adrian Shephard, an HECU Commander equipped with an experimental Military vest called the "PCV" or "Powered Combat Vest." Shephard and his squad are brought in early on during the Black Mesa incident, but Shephard is knocked out after their heli crashes. Because of this, you witness the end of Half-Life early on in the campaign, and see what happens after Gordon has already defeated the Nihilinth afterwards. After initial containment by the HECU is deemed a failure, the black ops are brought in to take out everyone through the use of a warhead. Shephard disarms the warhead, but it later detonates after the end of the game anyway. After fighting through hoards of Race X aliens and Black ops, Shephard finds himself in the depths of the industrial section of Black Mesa. Here, he encounters the Gene Worm, a giant Race X alien capable of processing and converting the entire planet into a habitat fit for Race X. Shephard kills it and is captured by the Gman, who keeps him in stasis, leaving the player to wonder what might happen to him next.

The story and gameplay tell a very different tale than that of Half-Life. You're not a super scientist saving the world in a big orange suit, you're a soldier on the losing side of a war fighting desperately to survive, knowing that the only way to win is to sacrifice Black Mesa and everyone in it. Opposing Force feels a lot like the Halo Reach of Half-Life. You don't feel anywhere near as Strong as Gordon Freeman, and you have to abandon and sacrifice your own squad members throughout the campaign just to keep going. With Opposing Force starting near the end of Half-Life, you can get a proper perspective of what's going on with the invasion outside of Gordon Freeman's point of view, and just how much damage is being dealt to the whole world. By the time you're fighting the gene worm, you don't feel like a hero, you feel like a tired soldier moments away from falling apart, just wanting it all to be over with. When the game ends, after the credit sequence, you aren't booted out into the main menu, you're given a black screen with the low whistling of wind, continuing on into eternity. The game's story is poetic, it puts you in the shoes of a member of the bad guys suffering the same fate as the good guys, and ends with an immense loss, especially considering what happens to humanity next. One can argue that Gordon Freeman's battle in Half-Life is the same, struggling to fight the oncoming invasion and somewhat losing at the end, but in Half-Life, you know what you did saved the world from the Xen invasion, whereas in Opposing Force, you don't have any orders being given to you by scientists or commanders, you're a lost soldier just doing what he can do to survive.

STORY SPOILERS END HERE.

With a story like that, usually I could give a raving 5 star review, but the gameplay is just too broken in the modern day for me to grace it with such. I would say "I hope Valve or Gearbox go back to fix these" but we both know they won't. It's 2020. With all that said and done, though, here's to Half-Life Alyx coming out in just a few days, and here's to Tripmine Studios for their Operation: Black Mesa and Guard Duty mods that they're developing!

[h1] DECEMBER 2020 UPDATE [/h1]
Yeah the game's still shit. I was genuinely glad when it finally crashed on me again so I could have a good excuse to stop playing. Wait for Operation: Black Mesa to come out or get it as part of the Valve complete pack. Don't get Op Force on its own, it's not worth it.

If you got any respect for the Half-Life franchise at all, take a huge step around this one. The GoldSource engine didn't age well, but where the original Half-Life game is carrying its dated environment with a certain sense of retro-nostalgic pride, Opposing Force at best shows how easy it is to fail the test of time.

I don't have enough toes and fingers to count in one gesture how many times I had to reload a quick save not due to challenge, but from getting stuck in elevators or cliffs from climbing up the god-awful ropes. Half the weapons in this game are forgettable and have no reason to be there other than some person at the dev conference brainstorming as much garbage as possible.

The only redeeming factor about this game at all is the ending, so do yourself a favor and watch a walkthrough on YouTube or something – you most certainly won't miss anything of importance.

游戏后期难度设计非常不合理，能把人打崩溃。补给太少是次要，主要的是这游戏伤害判定及其扯淡，黑衣人人均铁头娃，用M4打头部都要射十多发，倾倒所有M4子弹都杀不了几个敌人。再说说喝醋陆战队的队友，除了医疗兵和工兵有点用，其他都是来搞笑的，和几个黑衣人对射辣么久而无事发生，叫他跟着还不如杀了他捡枪来得实在。到了后期，外星敌人变得莫名其妙，貌似不是XEN的生物，然而战斗力比尼赫伦斯的部下强太多。有一种需要大量弹药倾倒才能消灭的怪物，在游戏后期疯狂地刷，就像有个生育机器一样。在剧情方面这游戏就更扯了，那些外星虫子不是尼赫伦斯的部下，难道是联合帝国直接派遣的？但他们也不符合联合帝国军队的特性。我知道你想展现谢泊德下士的英勇，但也没必要瞎搞设定吧，不玩不知道，打完了才明白为什么这一部的设定是不被VALVE承认的。最后，这游戏是我玩的所有半条命中让我打到最后连绊雷都用光的，不仅弹药奇缺，墙上的急救包和充电器也都能数得过来，G社真应该向VALVE学学怎么设计关卡难度。

Opposing Force is the better, longer expansion of Half-Life, but also the more tedious to play. Everything was a joy ride till the c*nts in black suit. They are ridiculously fast, extremely bullet-sponge because headshot means nothing, and they aim-bot you, some can even become invisible; meanwhile, you stuck with large meh collection of guns, that keep you questioning "Did I even hit anything?", and quite annoying to change in between by default binds. In addition, later levels design are all about tight and dark places, they keep spamming you tons of enemies, then you have to deal with the sh*tty nightvision that not only makes it harder to see the crosshair but also causes frame drops. It's not a decent challenge anymore but trial-and-error with F6/F7. The company AI is hilariously bad. The pathway could be confusing. The physics is detrimental with slippery movement and random stuck/damaging. It's just not fun toward the end.

In overall, the game can be enjoyable with normal, I believe it's around 6-7, but on Hard mode, cheap score for such cheap design 3-4. Thus came to the conclusion of 5 -average. And since Valve let me play it for free, that I don't have to buy it (and I won't) then I probably leave it recommended.

Or not, to hell with this game.
